main event: A report from Boston, Massachusetts on November 11th, 1948, described the sighting of three fast-flying single-engine planes, which were visible due to city lights and had no sound.
interesting points: The observer reported seeing the three aircraft flying east to west over the Charles River Basin, with the two outside planes in a straight line and the middle one weaving back and forth.
The objects were observed at approximately 5:00 A.M. at an altitude of 2000 feet and were estimated to be traveling at a speed of 150 mph.
Despite the lack of sound, the observer was able to identify them as single-engine planes, which seemed to be of a conventional type.
The objects were visible due to city lights, resembled three pale moths, and there was no evidence of exhaust or luminosity.
The reliability of the observer was questioned, as there was no evidence in police or FBI records, and the observer's associations indicated a potential bias.
witnesses: The observer, a retired organizer with affiliations with various organizations
